title: UNPOSED SPARSE VIEWS ROOM LAYOUT RECONSTRUCTION IN THE AGE OF PRETRAIN MODEL
author: Yaxuan Huang (Hong Kong Center for Construction Robotics, The Hong Kong University of Science and Technology), Xili Dai (The Hong Kong University of Science and Technology, Guangzhou), Jianan Wang (Astribot), Xianbiao Qi (Intellifusion Inc.), Yixing Yuan (Hong Kong Center for Construction Robotics, The Hong Kong University of Science and Technology), Xiangyu Yue (MMLab, The Chinese University of Hong Kong), ...
relevance_why: The proposed method could enhance understanding of 3D space, which can inform audio scene reconstruction tasks that require spatial awareness.
background: Room layout estimation involves reconstructing the geometry of indoor spaces from images taken from different perspectives, even when no camera poses are known.
contribution: This paper introduces Plane-DUSt3R to solve the multi-view room layout estimation task from unposed images, achieving improved accuracy and streamlined processing.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods often require known camera positions or rely on a complex multi-step process for geometry reconstruction.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work leverages a single-step, end-to-end approach that reduces error accumulation and simplifies the reconstruction workflow.

key_innovation: The integration of the DUSt3R framework allows for robust scene reconstruction from multiple unposed views without needing dense correspondences.
real_world_impact: This method has potential applications in AR and robotics, enhancing navigation and spatial awareness in complex environments without the need for extensive setup.
limitations: The method may face challenges in particularly cluttered scenes where occlusions obstruct plane detection.

new_terms.DUSt3R: **DUSt3R** refers to a recently developed framework for multi-view 3D reconstruction capable of generating scene reconstructions from unposed images.
new_terms.pointmap: **Pointmap** is a representation where each pixel in an image corresponds to a 3D point in the spatial world, aiding in geometry reconstruction.
